description: From Middle English feter, from Old English feter, Proto-West Germanic *fetur, from Proto-Germanic *feturaz (“fetter”), from Proto-Indo-European *ped- (“foot, step”). Cognate with Dutch veter (“lace”). Related to foot.

entries.meaning: A chain or similar object used to bind a person or animal – often by its legs (usually in plural).

verbs.description: fetter (third-person singular simple present fetters, present participle fettering, simple past and past participle fettered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To shackle or bind up with fetters.
(transitive) To restrain or impede; to hamper.
